metadata.case_name: Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within the Municipal limits of Amritsar except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib, Amritsar v. Respondents

facts.text: After the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 was passed, the then existing statutory Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee filed a list under section 3 claiming suit properties (Bunga Sarkar, Bunga Mai Mallan and appurtenant shops) as belonging to Gurdwara Harmandir Sahib.

Objections filed under section 8: Sardar Balwant Singh on 8th March 1928 claiming 1/3rd share in Bunga Mai Mallan and appurtenant shops; Sardar Raghbir Singh on 10th March 1928 claiming whole of Bunga Sarkar, its shops, and 1/3rd of Bunga Mai Mallan and shops.

Parties entered into compromises on 6th February 1930 in section 8 proceedings: some items admitted as private property, rest as wakf bungas for Yatris to Sri Darbar Sahib, to remain in management of claimants with stipulations.
Tribunal disposed of section 8 applications in terms of compromises. Managing Committee of Gurdwaras within Municipal limits of Amritsar (plaintiff's predecessor) party to compromises.

Prior to section 3 list and section 8 objections, petition under section 7 filed by 55 Sikhs claiming properties as Sikh Gurdwara 'Bunga Sarkar Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb' with list under section 7(2).
Government issued notification under section 7(3) on 18th February 1930.
Objections under section 8 by Granthis (not a Sikh Gurdwara); under section 10 by Sardar Raghbir Singh and Balwant Singh claiming private properties.
Tribunal on 28th August 1935 held Bunga Sarkar is a Sikh Gurdwara after contest by Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee.

Tribunal on 4th November 1935 in section 10 proceedings: declared some properties personal of claimants, rest as Sikh Gurdwaras appurtenant to Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan, vesting management in claimants per compromises.
Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and Managing Committee declined to be parties in section 10 proceedings.

High Court on appeal on 16th June 1936 deleted management directions from Tribunal decree, held properties declared personal remain personal, rest appurtenant to Gurdwaras (Bunga Sarkar including Bunga Mai Mallan as part thereof).
Government notification No. 9-G under section 17 dated 3rd March 1937 declaring suit properties as Sikh Gurdwara.
Plaintiff Committee filed suit under section 25-A on 25th February 1938 for possession.
Plaintiff Committee constituted prior to 1930, functioning by 6th February 1930 per section 85.
Sardar Balwant Singh died during High Court appeal in Regular First Appeal No. 73 of 1941; legal representatives not brought on record in time, appeal abated.
Sikh Gurdwaras Tribunal Lahore decree dated 19th December 1940 dismissing suit; High Court affirmed on 20th June 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether proceedings under section 10 resulted in declaration that properties constitute a Sikh Gurdwara.
Whether Tribunal had jurisdiction under section 10 to declare property as Sikh Gurdwara.
Whether decision contrary to section 37 and res judicata due to prior section 5 compromises.
Whether conduct of Committees (compromises without disclosing section 7 petition, declining parties, promoting contest) fraudulent, estopping reliance on section 10 decree.
Whether suit under section 25-A requires prior section 17 notification before section 10 decision.
Whether suit under section 25-A barred by limitation (one year from decision date 16th June 1936 or constitution of Committee).
Whether appeal abated due to death of Sardar Balwant Singh without bringing LRs on record.
Whether section 7(3) notification valid absent actual Gurdwara existence per prior section 5 compromises.

petitioner_arguments.text: Later section 10 proceedings and High Court judgment dated 16th June 1936 conclusive; with section 17 notification 3rd March 1937, entitled to possession under section 25-A notwithstanding earlier section 5 compromises.
Committee constituted for suit Gurdwara only from section 17 notification date (3rd March 1937), so limitation runs from then.

respondent_arguments.text: No specific declaration under section 10 that properties are Sikh Gurdwara.
Tribunal no jurisdiction under section 10 for positive Gurdwara declaration; only to decide if private property.
Decision contrary to section 37 and res judicata from section 5 compromises.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 section 37; res judicata

respondent_arguments.text: Committees' conduct fraudulent: compromises without disclosing section 7 petition, declined parties in section 10, promoted contest; estopped.
Section 25-A suit requires prior notification of Notified Sikh Gurdwara before section 10 decision.
Suit barred by limitation: filed 25th February 1938, beyond one year from High Court decision 16th June 1936; Committee constituted pre-1930.
Appeal abated on death of Sardar Balwant Singh; LRs not brought timely; joint claim.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of limitation decisive; unnecessary to decide other contentions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suit filed 25th February 1938 beyond one year from High Court decision 16th June 1936.

court_reasoning.text: Date of decision is High Court appeal disposal 16th June 1936. Limitation one year from that or Committee constitution, whichever later.
Plaintiff Committee constituted prior to 1930 per section 85 for Amritsar municipal Gurdwaras; date of constitution is notification date per section 88(2), but pre-existing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sections 85, 86, 88 do not deem new constitution date on section 17 notification.

court_reasoning.text: Section 86 policy (no committee till declaration) does not apply to section 85 Gurdwaras; cannot imply exception to section 88 deeming provision.
No hardship; section 25-A enabling cheap remedy; notification issued within 9 months, Committee had time to act.

holdings.text: Suit under section 25-A barred by limitation as filed beyond one year from decision date (16th June 1936) and Committee constituted earlier.

statutes_cited.name: Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 (Punjab Act VIII of 1925)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs claims, objections, declarations, notifications, committees, suits for possession, limitation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming High Court judgment affirming Tribunal's dismissal of suit, holding suit under section 25-A barred by limitation.

key_quotes.text: "the date of the publication of the notification shall be deemed to be the date of the constitution of the committee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Section 88(2) deeming provision key to rejecting petitioner's limitation argument.

key_quotes.text: "we do not consider that there is any question of hardship, because obviously section 25-A is only an enabling section providing a cheap remedy by way of a suit before the Tribunal itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains no extension of limitation despite potential delay in notification.
